q: Eric Schmidt drew fire for responding to a hypothetical question posed at a forum in Washington, DC, about an implant that would let Google Inc. know what its users were thinking. He responded that Google Inc. 's policy is to get right up to the creepy line and not cross it, and an implant would cross the line. He also said that as users voluntarily share information online, it doesn't need users to type in search queries for the company to tailor the results.

Tight end Brent Celek agreed, when he spoke via phone yesterday with a group of reporters from his minivacation getaway in Michigan: Sometimes he's taking some big-time hits, where maybe other guys would get flagged and he's not. Hopefully, they change it. He's a quarterback, too. He's the same as everybody else. Just because he's maybe a little bit more athletic and faster and can run, he shouldn't be penalized. Cyber attacks against the defense department as well as American-based companies like Google were at the heart of Kirsten Gillibrand 's complaint, prompting her to write that the potentially devastating consequences to the United States illustrate the need to engage this issue at the highest levels of government. The question of China's ability to restrict exports because of their control over REEs is also a problematic one for the Senator because these regulations sometimes force companies to relocate to China in order to access the materials.
